node.title: China locks down city of 13 million in bid to curb COVID outbreaks
node.description: The restrictions in Xi'an come just weeks before the Winter Olympics and are some of the harshest China has imposed since it locked down Wuhan after the coronavirus was first detected there in 2019.
node.content: ["Beijing \u2014 China is redoubling efforts to control new virus outbreaks with a lockdown of the 13 million residents of the northern city of Xi'an following a spike in coronavirus cases. The measure comes just weeks before the country hosts the Winter Olympics in Beijing, about 625 miles to the northeast. \u00a0 There was no word on whether the new Omicron variant of the coronavirus was fueling the surge in Xi'an, or the far more common Delta strain. China has confirmed just seven Omicron cases \u2014 four in the southern manufacturing center of Guangzhou, two in the southern city of Changsha and one in the northern port of Tianjin. \u00a0 China has also been dealing with a substantial COVID outbreak in several cities in the eastern province of Zhejiang near Shanghai, although isolation measures there have been more narrowly targeted.", "Authorities have adopted strict pandemic control measures under their policy of seeking to drive new transmissions to zero, leading to frequent lockdowns, universal masking and mass testing. While the policy has not been entirely successful and has led to massive disruptions of travel and trade, Beijing credits it with largely containing the spread of the virus. \u00a0 The Xi'an restrictions are some of the harshest since China in 2020 imposed a strict lockdown on more than 11 million people in and around the central city of Wuhan, where the coronavirus was first detected in late 2019. \u00a0 Xi'an on Thursday reported another 63 locally transmitted cases, pushing the city's total to at least 211 over the past week. Xi'an is the capital of Shaanxi province, famed for its imperial relics, as well as a major center of industry. \u00a0 \"We are not receiving any new guests and no present guests are allowed to leave the hotel,\" said a receptionist at the Hanting Hotel in Xi'an, who only gave her surname, Li. \u00a0 \"Including the guests, we are required to take a test once every two days.\" Li said. \"There will be an impact on our business and we have no idea how long it will last.\"", "The owner of a local bookshop said he had closed 10 days before, \"fearing the worsening of the epidemic situation.\" \u00a0 \"I am now staying at home watching television.\" said the owner, who gave only his surname, Xiao. \u00a0 Movement outside his compound requires permission from the local neighborhood committee, he said. \"I think the situation will get better eventually, and I don't worry at all because we have the government behind us,\" Xiao said. \u00a0 One person from each household will be allowed out every two days to buy household necessities, a government order said. It took effect at midnight Wednesday, with no word on when it might be lifted. \u00a0 China has reported 4,636 deaths among a total of 100,644 cases of COVID-19.", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
